org.hermann.controller

Class ChessActionListener

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.hermann.controller.ChessActionListener
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.util.EventListener

    public class ChessActionListener
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.awt.event.ActionListener
    Action listener for our JButtons in the MenuPanel and the items in our JMenubar, we'll only use one of them for all buttons/items so we won't have to write actions listeners for every single one of them. Also we don't need an extra instance for every single JButton.

      void actionPerformed(java.awt.event.ActionEvent e)
      So there are several ways to indicate which button/item caused the event and to decide which action to perform: We could either use the .getSource() method to know which object in particular was the source of the event or we could go with Adrian's way to use the .getActionCommand() method to receive the command string associated with the action.

      • ChessActionListener

    • Method Detail

      • actionPerformed

        public void actionPerformed(java.awt.event.ActionEvent e)
        So there are several ways to indicate which button/item caused the event and to decide which action to perform: We could either use the .getSource() method to know which object in particular was the source of the event or we could go with Adrian's way to use the .getActionCommand() method to receive the command string associated with the action. I decided for the .getActionCommand() method, because it will probably be easier to reuse some actions, if we have several event sources, which are supposed to perform the same action (for whatever reason). We'll only have label the button or item in the menubar with the same string to achieve the same functionality. Example: We already have an exit button in our control panel, but now we want another one in our menubar. If we used .getSource(), even if we use the same action lister, we would have to connect one action to several sources. However, if we use .getActionCommand(), we only need to connect the action to String "Exit" once and label both buttons "Exit".
        Specified by:
        actionPerformed in interface java.awt.event.ActionListener

      • getFrame

        public ChessGUI getFrame()

      • setFrame

        public void setFrame(ChessGUI frame)
